title: Ingersoll-Rand Has Soared This Year. One Analyst Says Its Time to Lighten Up.
text:
Text size

Ingersoll-Rand stock (IR) fell on Monday following a downgrade from Stephens, which warned that ongoing geopolitical and economic uncertainty could crimp earnings across the sector this quarter.

This isn’t the case of an analysts aligning their view with the market price. Ingersoll-Rand is up 28% in 2019, easily ahead of the S&P 500’s 17% gain, the Dow Jones Industrial Average’s 14% rise, and the 17% advance seen by the Industrial Select Sector SPDR ETF (XLI). The company reported an upbeat quarter in July, and analysts also applauded the company’s merger with Gardner Denver (GDI), announced this spring.

On Monday, Stephens analyst Rob McCarthy cut his rating on Ingersoll-Rand to Equal Weight from Overweight, with a $122 price target. The move comes as he also lowered his earnings per share estimates for the firm for 2019 and 2020, even as he writes that his previous estimates were already based on conservative figures.

He warns that there’s concern about the growth and sustainability of the current HVAC (heating, ventilation and air conditioning) cycle, and given that the shares have already outperformed year to date, he thinks that the risk-reward is more balance now, leading him to step to the sidelines.

Ingersoll-Rand dropped 1.8% to $116.45 in afternoon trading.

McCarthy’s downgrade of Ingersoll-Rand is part of a larger look at the industrial and electrical equipment sector, which resulted in hin trimming his estimates for a number of other companies. He cited weakness in the cycle, a deceleration of the macro backdrop, and ongoing political uncertainty—all of which are making businesses more reluctant to spend—for the changes. Outside the U.S., the economic picture is even less encouraging. Among his other Equal Weight-rated names, he writes that he is most worried about A.O. Smith (AOS), Lennox International (LII), and Regal Beloit (RBC) heading into earnings season.

That said, he thinks there are still some attractive names in the sector. He likes “quality compounders” like Roper Technologies (ROP), and Ametek (AME), and suggests buying any pullbacks in Rockwell Automation (ROK). He also thinks that Eaton (ETN) is likely to try to acquire Hubbell (HUBB), a deal he thinks could be wise.
